question:
During the reign of Akbar, _________ was the land that has lain fallow for three or four years.

SSC CGL 21/07/2023 (1st Shift)
solution:
• During Akbar's reign, land was classified for revenue assessment based on cultivation status.
  • Chachar referred to the land that had lain fallow for three or four years but could be made cultivable with little effort.
  • This was part of the Zabt system introduced by Raja Todar Mal, Akbar’s finance minister.
  • Other land types were:
    • Polaj: Land cultivated regularly and yielded crops every year.
    • Parauti: Land temporarily left fallow to regain fertility.
    • Banjar: Uncultivable and barren land, often abandoned or neglected.

question:
Agra Fort is one of the popular Mughal monuments built in the 16th century by ___________.

SSC MTS 04/05/2023 (Morning)
solution:
• Agra Fort is one of the most important and grand Mughal monuments of India.
  • It was built in the 16th century by Emperor Akbar in 1565, shortly after he made Agra his capital.
  • The fort was originally made of brick, but Akbar rebuilt it using red sandstone, making it a massive military structure and royal residence.
  • Later, emperors like Shah Jahan added more white marble structures inside it.
  • It served both as a military stronghold and the main residence of the Mughal emperors for generations.

question:
Which of the following cities was the first planned city of the Mughals?

SSC MTS 08/05/2023 (Evening)
solution:
• The first planned city of the Mughals was Fatehpur Sikri, built by Emperor Akbar in the 16th century.
  • It was constructed around 1571 to commemorate Akbar’s victory in Gujarat and to honour the Sufi saint Sheikh Salim Chishti, whose blessing led to the birth of Akbar’s heir, Jahangir.
  • The city was meticulously designed with palaces, mosques, administrative buildings, and courtyards, making it a model of Mughal urban planning.
  • Despite its grandeur, it was abandoned after around 15 years due to water scarcity and administrative reasons.

question:
When was the Battle of Tukaroi fought where Akbar defeated the Sultanate of Bengal and Bihar?

SSC MTS 15/05/2023 (Evening)
solution:
• The Battle of Tukaroi was fought in 1575 between the Mughal forces led by Munim Khan (Akbar’s general) and Daud Khan Karrani, the Sultan of Bengal and Bihar.
  • This battle marked a decisive Mughal victory, leading to the annexation of Bengal and Bihar into the Mughal Empire.
  • The battle took place near Tukaroi (also spelled Tukkaroi or Tukarain) in present-day Odisha.
  • After the battle, Daud Khan was forced to sign the Treaty of Katak, surrendering Bengal and Bihar to the Mughals while retaining only Orissa.
  • However, Daud later revolted, and he was finally defeated and killed in the Battle of Rajmahal (1576).

question:
Akbar's revenue system "Zabti" was developed by __________.

SSC MTS 15/06/2023 (Morning)
solution:
• Akbar’s revenue system, known as "Zabti", was developed by Raja Todar Mal, who was Akbar’s Finance Minister.
  • Under the Zabti system, land was measured and a fixed revenue rate was assessed based on the average produce and prices over the past 10 years.
  • This system aimed at standardising revenue collection and reducing the arbitrary demands by local officials.
  • The land was classified into types like Polaj, Parauti, Chachar, and Banjar, and revenue was assessed accordingly.
  • This method was implemented in northern India, particularly in areas with stable cultivation.

question:
Which singer was one of the Navaratnas (Nine Jewels) in the court of Mughal Emperor Jalal-ud-din Mohammad Akbar?

SSC CHSL 15/03/2023 (2nd Shift)
solution:
• Tansen was one of the Navaratnas (Nine Gems) in the court of Mughal Emperor Jalal-ud-din Mohammad Akbar.
  • He was a legendary Hindustani classical singer, originally named Ramtanu Pandey, and was given the title "Mian" by Akbar.
  • Tansen is credited with composing many ragas and is considered one of the founding figures of North Indian classical music.
  • Akbar held Tansen in such high regard that he made him one of the most honoured members of his court.

question:
__________ administration became the model followed by the great emperor Akbar when he consolidated the Mughal Empire.

SSC CHSL 15/03/2023 (4th Shift)
solution:
• Sher Shah Suri’s administration became the model that Akbar followed while consolidating and strengthening the Mughal Empire.
  • Sher Shah was a brilliant administrator and is credited with reforms in revenue collection, road construction, postal system, and land measurement.
  • His land revenue system, efficient bureaucracy, and use of standardised currency (Rupiya) heavily influenced Akbar’s own reforms.
  • Akbar adopted and improved many of Sher Shah's systems, especially through his finance minister Raja Todar Mal under the Zabti system.

question:
Who among the following wrote a history of Akbar's reign titled Akbar Nama?

SSC CHSL 17/03/2023 (4th Shift)
solution:
• The Akbar Nama was written by Abul Fazl, the court historian and one of the Navaratnas (Nine Gems) of Emperor Akbar’s court.
  • It is a three-volume historical work that documents the life and reign of Akbar in great detail.
  • The third volume of the Akbar Nama is known as the Ain-i-Akbari, which records the administration, culture, economy, and society of Akbar’s empire.
  • Abul Fazl wrote the Akbar Nama in Persian, the official language of the Mughal court.

question:
The city of Fatehpur Sikri was built by _________.

SSC CHSL 21/03/2023 (1st Shift)
solution:
• The city of Fatehpur Sikri was built by Emperor Akbar in the 16th century, around 1571 CE.
  • It was constructed to commemorate Akbar’s victory in Gujarat and to honour the Sufi saint Sheikh Salim Chishti, whose blessings were believed to have led to the birth of Akbar’s son, Jahangir.
  • Fatehpur Sikri served as the capital of the Mughal Empire for a brief period (1571–1585).
  • The city is a fine example of Mughal architecture, blending Indian, Persian, and Islamic styles.
  • However, it was later abandoned due to water scarcity and other logistical issues.

question:
Ain-i Akbari, a document on life of Mughal ruler Akbar does not contain information about __________.

SSC CHSL 21/03/2023 (4th Shift)
solution:
• The Ain-i-Akbari is the third volume of the Akbar Nama, written by Abul Fazl, and it documents the administration and daily life during Akbar's reign.
  • It includes detailed information about:
    • Revenue system
    • Army organisation
    • Mughal administration
    • Court customs, imperial household, religion, literature, and culture
  • However, Ain-i-Akbari does not focus on Akbar’s ancestors. That information is provided in the first volume of Akbar Nama, which details the genealogy and early life of Akbar and his forefathers.

question:
Ajmer became the suba headquarters under the __________.

SSC CGL 03/12/2022 (4th Shift)
solution:
• Ajmer became the suba (province) headquarters under the Mughals, particularly during the reign of Emperor Akbar.
  • The Mughal Empire was divided into several subas (provinces) for administrative convenience, and each suba had a headquarters city.
  • Ajmer was made the headquarters of the Ajmer Suba, due to its strategic location in Rajasthan and its religious significance (especially the Dargah of Khwaja Moinuddin Chishti).
  • It also served as an important military and administrative centre during the Mughal period.

question:
Who among the following is said to have devised many Raagas or melodies in Hindustani music?

SSC CGL 06/12/2022 (1st Shift)
solution:
• Tansen, one of the Navaratnas (Nine Gems) in Emperor Akbar's court, is renowned for his immense contribution to Hindustani classical music.
  • He is credited with creating or formalising many Raagas (melodic frameworks) that are still performed in Indian classical music today.
  • Some Raagas attributed to Tansen include Miyan ki Todi, Miyan ki Malhar, and Darbari Kanada.
  • Tansen’s musical genius earned him the title "Miyan" from Akbar, and he is considered one of the founding figures of North Indian classical music.

question:
In which year was Kashmir annexed to the Mughal Empire by Akbar?

Graduate Level 01/08/2022 (Shift-4)
solution:
• Kashmir was annexed to the Mughal Empire by Emperor Akbar in the year 1586.
  • Prior to this, Kashmir was ruled by the Chak dynasty. The Chaks initially resisted Mughal advances.
  • Akbar sent military expeditions under Qasim Khan and Mirza Yusuf Khan, and after a prolonged campaign, the Mughal forces successfully brought Kashmir under imperial control.
  • The annexation of Kashmir allowed Akbar to strengthen Mughal influence in the north-western Himalayan region, important for both strategic and trade purposes.

question:
Who among the following was Akbar's revenue minister?

SSC MTS 06/07/2022 (Morning)
solution:
• Raja Todar Mal was Akbar’s revenue minister and one of the most important figures in his administration.
  • He is credited with developing and implementing the Zabti system—a systematic and scientific method of land revenue assessment.
  • Todar Mal introduced standardised land measurement units, survey techniques, and average-based taxation to make the revenue system more efficient and fair.
  • His reforms laid the foundation for the modern land revenue system in India.

question:
The revenue system of the Mughal period during Akbar's reign was called ___________.

SSC MTS 26/07/2022 (Evening)
solution:
• The revenue system of the Mughal Empire during Akbar’s reign was known as the Zabti system.
  • It was introduced and implemented by Raja Todar Mal, Akbar’s finance minister.
  • Under this system:
    • Land was measured and categorised based on fertility and cultivation frequency.
    • The average produce and prices of the past 10 years were used to fix a standardised tax.
    • The tax was usually paid in cash, which improved administrative efficiency and reduced corruption.
  • Zabti was most effective in regions where cultivation was regular and consistent.

question:
As described in 'Ain-i-Akbari' by Abul Fazl-i-Allami, 'gaz' (unit of measuring length) was divided into equal parts called .

SSC CGL 20/04/2022 (Morning)
solution:
• As per the 'Ain-i-Akbari' written by Abul Fazl-i-Allami, during Akbar’s reign, the unit of length known as "gaz" was used for land measurement.
  • The gaz was divided into smaller equal parts called "tassuj".
  • This standardisation was part of Raja Todar Mal’s revenue reforms, which aimed to create a uniform and accurate system for land measurement and taxation.
  • The implementation of such precise units helped ensure fair revenue assessment across the empire.

question:
Sikandra is the final resting place of Emperor __________.

SSC CGL 20/04/2022 (Morning)
solution:
• Sikandra is the final resting place of Emperor Akbar, located near Agra, Uttar Pradesh.
  • The construction of the tomb of Akbar was started by Akbar himself and completed by his son Jahangir after Akbar’s death in 1605.
  • The tomb is a fine example of Mughal architecture, blending Islamic, Hindu, Buddhist, and Jain styles, reflecting Akbar's policy of religious tolerance.
  • It is one of the major historical monuments and an important tourist attraction in India today.

question:
Military commanders in Akbar's empire were called ‘’.

SSC MTS 11/10/2021 (Afternoon)
solution:
• In Akbar’s empire, the military commanders responsible for maintaining law and order and commanding military forces in the provinces were called "Faujdars".
  • A Faujdar was in charge of a district or region, overseeing the army and ensuring internal peace and security.
  • They reported to the Subahdar (provincial governor) and played a vital role in enforcing the emperor's authority in the provinces.
  • Other terms in the options:
    • Bakhshi: Responsible for military administration and payment to soldiers.
    • Kotwal: In charge of city policing and municipal administration.
    • Diwan: Managed revenue and finance of the province.

question:
Who among the following issued Mahzarnama in 1579?

SSC CGL 23/08/2021 (Evening)
solution:
• The Mahzarnama was issued by Emperor Akbar in 1579.
  • It was a royal edict (also known as the Declaration of Faith) that gave Akbar the final authority in religious matters, even over the Islamic ulema (religious scholars).
  • Through the Mahzarnama, Akbar declared that if there was any disagreement among Islamic scholars, the emperor had the right to choose the correct interpretation.
  • This move was part of Akbar’s broader policy of religious tolerance and centralisation of power, and it laid the foundation for his Din-i Ilahi in 1582.

question:
Which Mughal emperor built the city called 'Makhsudabad' later popularly known as Murshidabad?

SSC CHSL 12/04/2021 (Afternoon)
solution:
• The city Makhsudabad, which later became popular as Murshidabad, was originally established during the reign of Emperor Akbar.
  • It gained prominence under the governorship of Murshid Quli Khan, the Diwan (later Nawab) of Bengal, who shifted the capital of Bengal from Dhaka to Makhsudabad in the early 18th century.
  • In honour of himself, he renamed the city Murshidabad, and it became the capital of Bengal Subah under the Mughals.
  • Although Akbar laid the administrative groundwork, the city flourished and was renamed during the reign of Aurangzeb, not Shah Jahan or Humayun.

Note: While the question gives Akbar as the correct answer, the actual transformation of Makhsudabad into Murshidabad is historically attributed to Murshid Quli Khan under Aurangzeb’s rule.

question:
In the context of Mughal administration, which of the following is the most appropriate definition of 'Abwab'?

SSC CHSL 16/04/2021 (Evening)
option_1: A clerk in the government treasury
option_3: A tax levied on the lands over and above the original rent
option_4: A reward for good governance
solution:
• In the context of Mughal administration, ‘Abwab’ refers to additional taxes levied on land over and above the original rent (main land revenue).
  • Though not part of the standard revenue system, abwab were often collected by local officials and became a burden on the peasants.
  • These taxes were frequently arbitrary or irregular, leading to resentment among cultivators.
  • Later Mughal emperors and revenue reformers like Raja Todar Mal sought to reduce or eliminate abwab to streamline and standardise the revenue system.

question: Akbar was crowned as emperor in 1556 at which place?
solution:
• Akbar was crowned as the Mughal Emperor in the year 1556 at a place called Kalanaur, which is located in present-day Punjab.
  • This coronation took place shortly after the death of his father, Humayun.
  • At the time of his accession, Akbar was only 13 years old, and the actual administration was handled by his regent and guardian, Bairam Khan, until Akbar assumed full control.
  • The event marked the beginning of one of the most significant reigns in Indian history.

question: Who acted as the regent of Akbar during the early years of his reign?
solution:
• During the early years of Akbar’s reign, the empire was in a fragile state after the sudden death of Emperor Humayun in 1556.
  • At that time, Akbar was only 13 years old and too young to rule independently. Therefore, the Mughal administration needed a strong and experienced leader to guide the empire through this transitional phase.
  • Bairam Khan, a senior noble and loyal general of Humayun, was appointed as regent (wakil or guardian) of Akbar. He held the title of Khan-i-Khanan, meaning "Lord of Lords".
  • Bairam Khan played a crucial role in consolidating the empire during this delicate period:
    • He supervised Akbar’s coronation at Kalanaur in 1556.
    • He led the Mughal army in the Second Battle of Panipat (1556), defeating Hemu, the Hindu general of the Sur dynasty, thereby securing the Mughal throne for Akbar.
    • Under his regency, many administrative reforms were initiated, and the foundation of a strong central government was laid.
  • Eventually, when Akbar matured and decided to take full control of the empire in 1560, Bairam Khan was politely dismissed and later assassinated while on a pilgrimage to Mecca.

question: Akbar fought the Second Battle of Panipat in 1556 against:
solution:
• The Second Battle of Panipat was fought on 5th November 1556 between the Mughal forces led by Bairam Khan (on behalf of the young emperor Akbar) and the forces of Hemu, a capable Hindu general and the Chief Minister of Adil Shah Suri of the declining Sur Dynasty.
  • After Humayun's death, Hemu seized Delhi and declared himself ruler, adopting the title "Vikramaditya".
  • To reclaim Delhi and secure the Mughal throne, Bairam Khan marched north with Akbar’s army.
  • The battle took place at Panipat (present-day Haryana), the same place where Babur had fought the First Battle of Panipat in 1526.
  • Though Hemu's army initially gained the upper hand, a stray arrow struck his eye, and he collapsed unconscious. His troops, losing morale, scattered, leading to a decisive Mughal victory.
  • This battle was crucial in re-establishing the Mughal Empire in India under Akbar’s leadership.

question: Akbar’s policy of Sulh-i-Kul promoted:
option_3: Universal peace and tolerance
solution:
• Sulh-i-Kul, meaning “peace with all”, was a key principle of Akbar’s policy of governance.
  • It promoted universal peace, religious tolerance, and harmony among all communities, regardless of religion or caste.
  • This policy emerged from Akbar’s realisation that ruling over a multi-religious and multicultural empire required a broad-minded and inclusive approach.
  • Under Sulh-i-Kul:
    • All religions were respected, and discriminatory taxes like jizya (on non-Muslims) were abolished.
    • Akbar engaged in interfaith dialogues at the Ibadat Khana in Fatehpur Sikri, inviting scholars from various religions—Hinduism, Islam, Jainism, Christianity, Zoroastrianism, etc.
    • This policy later became the ideological basis for his Din-i Ilahi, though that was a personal spiritual initiative rather than a state religion.

question: Akbar’s Din-i-Ilahi was essentially a:
option_3: Political treaty with Rajputs
option_4: Religious-philosophical path combining various faiths
solution:
• Din-i-Ilahi, meaning “Religion of God”, was a religious-philosophical path introduced by Emperor Akbar in 1582 CE.
  • It was not a new religion in the conventional sense, but rather an ethical and spiritual system combining elements from various faiths including:
    • Islam (Akbar's birth religion)
    • Hinduism
    • Zoroastrianism
    • Christianity
    • Jainism
  • The aim was to promote tolerance, ethical living, and respect for all religions, thus reflecting Akbar’s broader policy of Sulh-i-Kul (universal peace).
  • Din-i-Ilahi emphasised:
    • Monotheism
    • Piety
    • Rejection of sectarianism
    • Loyalty to the emperor
  • It was never widely accepted and remained limited to a small group of loyal courtiers such as Birbal.
  • It was more of a personal spiritual path of Akbar rather than a mass movement or state religion.

question: Which Mughal emperor abolished the jizya tax on non-Muslims?
solution:
• Jizya was a religious tax imposed on non-Muslims (dhimmis) under Islamic rule.
  • Emperor Akbarabolished Jizya in 1564 to promote religious tolerance and equality.
  • This move was part of his broader policy of Sulh-i-Kul (universal peace).
  • It helped in winning the loyalty of Hindu subjects, especially the Rajputs.
  • The abolition reflected Akbar’s efforts to create a secular and inclusive empire.
  • Aurangzeb later reimposed the Jizya in 1679, reversing Akbar’s tolerant policy.

question: Which Rajput ruler did Akbar defeat in the Battle of Haldighati (1576)?
solution:
• The Battle of Haldighati was fought on 18 June 1576 between the Mughal army led by Man Singh I (a Rajput general loyal to Akbar) and the Rajput forces of Mewar led by Maharana Pratap.
  • The battle took place at Haldighati Pass in present-day Rajasthan.
  • Akbar aimed to subjugate Mewar, one of the few Rajput states that had not accepted Mughal supremacy.
  • Though Maharana Pratap fought valiantly, he was eventually defeated and had to retreat into the hills.
  • However, the Mughals failed to capture Maharana Pratap, and he continued guerrilla warfare against them for years.
  • The battle is remembered for the bravery of Maharana Pratap and his horse Chetak.

question: Akbar’s Navaratnas included all except:
solution:
• Akbar’s Navaratnas (Nine Gems) were a group of nine extraordinary courtiers known for their talent, wisdom, and contributions to the Mughal court.
  • They included:
    • Birbal – known for wit and intelligence.
    • Raja Todar Mal – Akbar’s finance minister, who developed the Zabti revenue system.
    • Abul Fazl – Akbar’s court historian and author of Akbarnama and Ain-i-Akbari.
  • Shah Jahan, however, was not one of Akbar’s Navaratnas; he was Akbar’s grandson and became emperor much later in 1628.
  • Hence, among the options, Shah Jahan does not belong to Akbar’s Navaratnas.

question: Who was Akbar’s official court historian and author of Akbarnama?
solution:
• Abul Fazl was Akbar’s official court historian and the author of the Akbarnama, a detailed chronicle of Akbar’s reign.
  • The Akbarnama is divided into three volumes:
    • The first two volumes narrate the history of Akbar's ancestors and Akbar's life and rule.
    • The third volume, called Ain-i-Akbari, describes the administration, culture, military, economy, and daily life during Akbar’s reign.
  • Abul Fazl was also one of Akbar’s Navaratnas (Nine Gems) and was known for his intellect and scholarship.
  • He played a significant role in shaping Akbar’s policy of Sulh-i-Kul (universal peace) and supported the concept of Din-i-Ilahi.

question: Which city was designed as Akbar’s capital and later abandoned due to water scarcity?
solution:
• Fatehpur Sikri was designed and built by Emperor Akbar in the late 16th century, around 1571 CE, to serve as the capital of the Mughal Empire.
  • The city was established to commemorate Akbar’s victory over Gujarat and in honour of the Sufi saint Sheikh Salim Chishti, whose blessing was believed to have led to the birth of Akbar’s heir, Jahangir.
  • It was a planned city, showcasing Mughal architecture with a blend of Persian, Indian, and Islamic styles.
  • Important structures within Fatehpur Sikri include the Buland Darwaza, Jama Masjid, Diwan-i-Khas, Panch Mahal, and Salim Chishti’s tomb.
  • However, due to acute water shortage and logistical difficulties, the city was abandoned after around 15 years and the capital was shifted back to Agra.
  • Today, Fatehpur Sikri is a UNESCO World Heritage Site and a major historical tourist attraction.

question: What was the Mansabdari system introduced by Akbar?
option_2: A system of ranking military and civil officials
option_4: System for temple grants
solution:
• The Mansabdari system was introduced by Emperor Akbar as a way to organise and rank military and civil officials within the Mughal administration.
  • The term "Mansab" means rank or position, and each official (called a Mansabdar) was assigned a numerical rank that determined:
    • Their status in the imperial court
    • The number of cavalry (sawar) they had to maintain
    • Their salary and responsibilities
  • The two main components of the system were:
    • Zat – indicated the personal rank and salary of the officer.
    • Sawar – indicated the number of horsemen the officer had to maintain for military service.
  • This system helped Akbar centralise authority, prevent feudal fragmentation, and strengthen control over the nobility.
  • It remained a key administrative feature throughout the Mughal period.

question: Raja Man Singh was appointed governor of which region by Akbar?
solution:
• Raja Man Singh, one of the most trusted generals and a member of Akbar’s Navaratnas, was appointed the Governor (Subahdar) of Bengal by Emperor Akbar.
  • This appointment came after his successful military campaigns and loyalty to the Mughal crown.
  • Bengal was a strategically important and volatile province, known for its wealth but also for frequent rebellions and resistance to Mughal authority.
  • As governor, Man Singh effectively suppressed revolts, implemented Akbar’s policies, and strengthened Mughal control in the region.
  • He also played a key role in expanding the Mughal Empire into the eastern territories.
  • His governance in Bengal helped consolidate Mughal rule in that economically vital region.

question: Akbar’s revenue minister Todar Mal is credited for:
option_2: Developing land revenue system based on measurement
solution:
• Raja Todar Mal, the revenue minister of Emperor Akbar, is best known for developing a systematic land revenue system based on accurate land measurement.
  • He introduced the Zabti or Bandobast system, which became the backbone of Akbar’s revenue administration.
  • Under this system:
    • Land was measured using standardized units like gaz and subdivided into categories based on fertility.
    • Revenue was assessed based on average produce and prices of the past 10 years.
    • Taxes were fixed and usually paid in cash, ensuring predictability and fairness.
  • This system helped reduce arbitrary tax collection and strengthened centralised control over local landholders.
  • Todar Mal’s reforms laid the foundation for future revenue systems even under British rule.

question: The Ibadat Khana established by Akbar was meant for:
solution:
• The Ibadat Khana (meaning "House of Worship") was established by Emperor Akbar in 1575 CE at Fatehpur Sikri.
  • It was intended as a venue for inter-religious spiritual discussions and debates among scholars of different faiths.
  • Initially, only Muslim scholars participated, but later Akbar invited scholars from various religions including Hinduism, Jainism, Zoroastrianism, Christianity, and Judaism.
  • The Ibadat Khana reflected Akbar's intellectual curiosity, religious tolerance, and efforts to find a common ethical and spiritual ground.
  • These discussions influenced Akbar’s ideas and ultimately led to the formation of Din-i-Ilahi, his own spiritual doctrine.
  • It symbolised Akbar's vision of Sulh-i-Kul (universal peace and harmony).

question: Which of the following policies helped Akbar gain Rajput support?
option_2: Abolition of land tax
option_4: Promotion of Persian only
solution:
• Matrimonial alliances were a key component of Akbar’s Rajput policy, aimed at securing loyalty and political stability.
  • Instead of relying solely on conquest, Akbar formed alliances through marriage with several Rajput families.
  • The most famous alliance was with Raja Bharmal of Amber, whose daughter Harka Bai (popularly known as Jodha Bai) married Akbar.
  • Through these alliances, Rajput rulers retained their positions, honour, and autonomy, while becoming loyal Mughal allies.
  • This helped Akbar to integrate Rajputs into the Mughal administration, many of whom became high-ranking mansabdars and governors.
  • The policy ensured long-term cooperation and played a major role in the expansion and stability of the Mughal Empire.

question: Who among the following was NOT part of Akbar’s Navaratnas?
solution:
• Akbar’s Navaratnas or Nine Gems were a group of nine extraordinary courtiers who served in Akbar’s court and contributed in various fields such as administration, literature, music, finance, and military.
  • Among the well-known Navaratnas were:
    • Tansen – Legendary musician of Akbar's court.
    • Abdul Rahim Khan-i-Khanan – Poet, military commander, and scholar known for his dohas (couplets).
    • Raja Birbal – Celebrated for his wit and intelligence.
  • In contrast, Shah Jahan was not part of Akbar’s court; he was Akbar’s grandson and became emperor much later in 1628 CE.
  • Therefore, he does not belong to the group of Navaratnas that served during Akbar’s reign.

question: Which language did Akbar patronize for administrative and literary purposes?
solution:
• Emperor Akbar patronised Persian as the official language of the Mughal Empire for both administrative and literary purposes.
  • All royal edicts, court proceedings, and official correspondence were conducted in Persian.
  • It served as a link language among various regions of the empire and was widely used by scholars, poets, and administrators.
  • Akbar also encouraged translation of important Sanskrit texts (like the Mahabharata and Ramayana) into Persian to promote cultural integration.
  • Notable Persian works from his court include Akbarnama and Ain-i-Akbari, written by Abul Fazl.
  • Persian remained the dominant administrative language in India until the British period, when it was replaced by English.

question: Which region remained largely unconquered by Akbar during his lifetime?
solution:
• During Akbar’s reign, the Mughal Empire expanded significantly across northern, central, and parts of southern India.
  • He successfully annexed Gujarat, Orissa, and parts of Mewar after intense military campaigns.
  • However, Assam, located in the far northeast, largely remained unconquered during his lifetime.
  • The Mughal attempts to expand into the Brahmaputra Valley were met with strong resistance from the Ahom kingdom of Assam.
  • The Ahoms had a powerful local military and used guerrilla tactics effectively in the dense terrain, which made it difficult for the Mughals to establish control.
  • Thus, Assam continued to retain its independence from Mughal rule during Akbar’s reign.

question: Akbar’s Deccan campaigns were aimed at:
option_3: Bringing Khandesh, Berar and Ahmadnagar under Mughal control
solution:
• Akbar’s Deccan campaigns were primarily aimed at bringing the Deccan Sultanates under Mughal control.
  • Specifically, his focus was on annexing Khandesh, Berar, and Ahmadnagar, which were important strategic and wealthy regions in the Deccan plateau.
  • Controlling these territories allowed the Mughals to:
    • Expand their empire southwards.
    • Secure important trade routes and military advantages.
    • Counter the influence of the Bijapur and Golconda Sultanates.
  • Akbar’s campaigns in the Deccan laid the foundation for further Mughal expansion under his successors, especially Aurangzeb.
  • The campaigns were political and military in nature, rather than focused on religious conversion or temple building.
